title: A flow-cytometry-based assay to assess the cytolytic activity against tumor cells by combination of mouse MAIT cells and natural killer cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
      Differentiation of reMAIT cells from MAIT cell-derived iPSCs
    
Timing: ∼3 weeks
      Here, we describe each step for differentiating MAIT-like cells (reMAIT
      cells) from MAIT cell-derived iPSCs (MAIT-iPSCs), partially modifying a
      previous protocol on T cell differentiation from mouse ES cells using
      OP9/DLL1 cells.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
        iPSC culture on OP9/DLL1 (Day 0).
        
            Take day-4 to -5 OP9/DLL1 dishes (see step 4 in
            before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin],
            Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) from the incubator and replace the
            medium with 9 mL of Differentiation medium (stored at 4°C up to
            1 month).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3084-Fig1.jpg
                  Figure 1. reMAIT cell differentiation from MAIT-iPSCs on
                  OP9/DLL1 monolayer
                
                  (A) OP9/DLL1 monolayer on day 4 after seeding on
                  gelatin-coated dish. This picture shows optimal confluency for
                  initiation of reMAIT cell differentiation.
                
                  (B) After the medium change on day 3, a rapid morphological
                  change is observed, and by day 5, mesodermal cell masses with
                  raised center are formed.
                
                  (C) Mesodermal cells differentiate into lymphoblasts on new
                  OP9/DLL1 in the presence of FLT3-L (Day 8). Lymphoblasts have
                  a grape cluster-like morphology.
                
                  (D) Lymphoblasts differentiate into reMAIT cells and reMAIT
                  cells are expanding in the presence of FLT3-L and IL-7.
                
                  (E) The proliferating reMAIT cells can be transferred onto a
                  new OP9/DLL1 monolayer (10-cm culture dish) from 6-well plate
                  and let them grow until they cover the entire surface of
                  OP9/DLL1. (A-E) Each bar in the images indicates 200 μm.
                
                  (F) Almost all T cells induced from MAIT cell-derived iPSCs
                  are MR1-tetramer positive and TCRβ+ cells (but not
                  recognized by 6-FP-loaded MR1 tetramer).
                
            Prepare iPSC single cell suspension (see step 5 and 6 in
            before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]).
          
            Count the cells and resuspend them at a concentration of
            1.2 × 105 cells/mL in Differentiation medium.
          
Seed 1 mL of iPSC suspension per 10-cm OP9/DLL1 dish.
Return the plates to the CO2 incubator.

Medium change (Day 3).
        
Remove all the medium.
Add 10 mL of Differentiation medium.
Return the dishes to the CO2 incubator.
        Harvesting mesodermal cells (Day 5, Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
        
            Remove the medium from the dish in which rosebud-shaped cell
            clusters have formed.
          
Wash the dish with 5 mL of PBS twice.
Spread 2 mL of 0.25% Trypsin-1 mM EDTA evenly on the dish.
            Incubate the dish in a 5% CO2 incubator at 37°C for
            3–5 min.
          
            Confirm that the cells are detached and add 8 mL of OP9 medium.
          
            Using a 1000-μL tip, disrupt the cell clumps by slightly vigorous
            but not bubbly pipetting (about 15 times).
          
            Place the dishes in the CO2 incubator for 45–60 min to
            re-adhere OP9/DLL1 cells onto the dish.
          
            Collect the medium containing floating cells with a 10-mL pipette
            and pass them through a 40 μm cell strainer.
          
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
            Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cells in 10 mL of
            differentiation medium.
          
            Add 0.5 μL of 100 μg/mL FLT3-L per 10 mL of the cell suspension
            (final concentration 5 ng/mL).
          
            Prepare new OP9/DLL1 dish (see step 4 in
            before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]) and remove the
            medium.
          
            Spread the cell suspension with FLT3-L to a new OP9/DLL1 dish.
          
Return the dishes to the CO2 incubator.
        Harvesting lymphoblasts (Day 8, Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
        
            Take up the medium from the dish with a 10-mL pipette and use it to
            wash the surface with sufficient force not to break the OP9/DLL1
            monolayer. Such pipetting allows semi-adherent blast cells to be
            detached from the OP9/DLL1 monolayer.
          
            Once sufficient pipetting has been completed, transfer the cell
            suspension into a 50-mL conical tube through a 40 μL cell strainer.
          
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.

Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cells in 2 mL of reMAIT
            medium (stored at 4°C up to 10 days) per 10-cm dish.
          
            Seed 2 mL of cell suspension per well of a 6-well plate with the
            OP9/DLL1 monolayer.
          
        Medium change (Day 10, 12, 14, Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).
        
Remove all the medium.
Add 2 mL of reMAIT medium per well.
Return the plates to the CO2 incubator.
        Expansion of reMAIT cells (Day 16 or later,
        Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E).
        
            When the round, shiny cells grow to cover the OP9/DLL1 monolayer,
            remove them by pipetting with sufficient force not to break the
            OP9/DLL1 monolayer and collect the cell suspension into a 15-mL
            conical tube.
          
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
            Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cells in 10 mL of reMAIT
            medium.
          
Seed the cell suspension onto a new 10-cm OP9/DLL1 dish.
            Change the half of medium every other day or split the expanded
            cells into additional dishes.
          
        Flow cytometry analysis for reMAIT cells (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
        
            Remove differentiated cells (reMAIT cells) from the OP9/DLL1
            monolayer by pipetting.
          
            Replace 1 × 104 – 5 × 104 cells into a well of
            96-well plate or a FACS tube.
          
            Wash the cells with FACS buffer (stored at 4°C up to 3 months).
          
            Resuspend the cells in the reaction mixture below containing the
            antibodies and MR1 tetramer for phenotyping.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_15.csv
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 20 min.
Wash the cells with FACS buffer.
            Resuspend the cells in FACS buffer containing 7-AAD (dead/live
            discrimination; dilution 1:200, stored at 4°C up to 6 months).
          
            Acquire the cells with a flow cytometer.
            
Critical: OP9/DLL1 dishes
              should be used within 4–5 days after preparation; if OP9/DLL1
              dishes are older than 4–5 days, iPSCs may not adhere.
            
Critical: MAIT-iPSCs should

not exceed 80% of the confluency during culture (before starting
              differentiation on OP9/DLL1). Overconfluent cells should not be
              used for differentiation step, as they show poor differentiation
              potential.
            
Note: Morphological changes of the
              cells during differentiation are shown in
              Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A–1E. Almost all T cells induced from
              MAIT-iPSCs are MR1-tetramer positive MAIT cells (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F). This is because MAIT-iPSCs harbor the MAIT cell-specific TCR
              gene rearrangement.9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]
Pause point: reMAIT cells
              in the early logarithmic proliferative stage (normally on day
              18–22) can be cryopreserved. Frozen reMAIT cells can be grown
              again on OP9/DLL1 dish with 20% FBS/αMEM containing IL-7 (reMAIT
              medium without FLT3-L) for further experiments.
            
Preparation of mouse NK cells from C57BL/6
Timing: 3 h
      Coexistence of MAIT and NK cells enhances the cytolytic activity against
      cancer cells more than each alone. Here the process of isolation and
      purification of NK cells from the mouse spleen is shown. Although
      isolation kits are available from various vendors, we use the BioLegend
      MojoSort Mouse NK cell isolation kit (BioLegend) combined with LS columns
      (Miltenyi Biotec).
    
        Isolate the spleens from three euthanized 8- to 12-week-old C57BL/6
        mice.
      
        Place a 40 μm cell strainer in a 10 cm petri dish and place the spleens
        on the strainer.
      
        Add 3–4 mL of cR10 and mush the spleens with a gasket portion of the
        plunger of a 2.5-mL syringe to strain out the cells.
      
        Transfer the cell suspension into a 15-mL tube, rinse the petri dish
        with another 5 mL of cR10, and collect in a 15-mL tube.
      
        Centrifuge at 400 × g for 4 min and aspirate the supernatant.
      
        Add 3 mL of 67% Percoll (stored at 4°C up to 3 months) into a new 15-mL
        tube.
      
        Suspend the cell pellet from step 12 with 8 mL of 40% Percoll (stored at

4°C up to 3 months).
      
        Set the pipettor’s dispense speed to low and slowly layer the cell
        suspension in 40% Percoll above 3 mL of 67% Percoll with a 10-mL
        pipette.
      
Note: At this time, the tube is tilted at
      an angle of about 30 degrees from the table surface and the cell
      suspension is added so that it flows down along the inner wall, forming a
      transparent layer.
    
        Centrifuge at 400 × g for 20 min at 20°C–25°C with break-off.
      
        Collect a white layer of cells at the boundary of the two Percoll layers
        into a new 15-mL tube.
      
Fill up the tube with PBS and mix well by inverting the tube.
Centrifuge at 700 × g for 7 min.
        Aspirate the supernatant and suspend the cells in 10 mL of MACS buffer
        (stored at 4°C up to 3 months).
      
Filter the cell suspension with 40 μm cell strainer.
        Count the cells. Usually, 3–5 × 107 cells can be recovered
        from three spleens.
      
        Adjust the cell concentration at 1 × 108/mL with MACS buffer.
      
        Add 2 μL of biotin antibody cocktail per 1 × 107 cells.
      
Incubate on ice for 15 min.
        Add 5 mL of MACS buffer and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min.
      
Suspend the cells in MACS buffer at 1 × 108/mL.
Add 2 μL of streptavidin nanobeads per 1 × 107 cells.
Incubate on ice for 15 min.
        Add 5 mL of MACS buffer and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min.
      
Suspend the cells in 5 mL of MACS buffer.
        Collect magnetic beads negative fraction using LS column.
        
Place the LS column in a magnetic separator.
Equilibrate the LS column with 3 mL of MACS buffer.
            Set an empty 15-mL conical tube under the LS column to collect the

cell fraction that is not attached to the magnet (negative
            fraction).
          
            Apply the cell suspension from step 31 to the LS column through a
            40 μm cell strainer or screen mesh and collect the fraction that
            passes through the LS column.
          
            After the liquid has completely entered the column, wash the LS
            column with 3 mL of MACS buffer, and collect it in the tube as well.
          
Repeat step 32-e one more time.
        Centrifuge the collected cell fraction at 400 × g for 5 min.
      
Suspend the cells with 3 mL of cR10.
Count the cells.
        Take 1 × 104 cells in a 96-well plate well or a FACS tube.
      
        Add the following reaction mixture to check the purity of NK cells.
      
table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_16.csv
Incubate at 20–25°C for 20 min in the dark.
Wash the cells with FACS buffer.
        Resuspend the cells in FACS buffer containing 7-AAD (dead/live
        discrimination).
      
Acquire the cells with a flow cytometer.
Note: An average of 1.5 × 108
      spleen cells can be obtained from three C57BL/6 mice, from which 1.5 to
      5 × 106 NK cells can be isolated. Flow cytometric analysis of
      the final product shows that approximately 50–60% are
      NK1.1+CD49b+ (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3084-Fig2.jpg
          Figure 2. NK cell isolation from C57BL/6 spleen cells
        
          Mouse NK cells isolated by negative selection with magnetic microbeads
          were stained with NK1.1 and CD49b. Representative data are shown. The
          number in the quadrant shows the percentage of each subset.
        
Critical: Be sure to add 2 μL of
      biotin antibody cocktail per 1 × 107 cells. Adding less
      antibody would compromise the purity of NK cells.
    
Cytolytic activity of reMAIT cells against YAC-1
Timing: 1 day
      Since YAC-1 is a lymphoma, it is difficult to distinguish it from MAIT
      cells, which are also T lymphocytes, on scatter plots in the flow

cytometric analysis. Therefore, prior to co-culture with reMAIT cells,
      YAC-1 is fluorescently labeled by incorporating CFSE. After co-culture,
      the cells are stained with live/dead reagent. Flow cytometric analysis
      will reveal the cytolytic activity of reMAIT cells against YAC-1 by gating
      CSFE-labeled YAC-1 and measuring the percentage of dying or dead cells in
      YAC-1.
    
        CFSE labeling of YAC-1.
        
Prepare 1 × 106 YAC-1.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in pre-warmed 1 mL of 1 μM CFSE in PBS.
Incubate at 37°C for 15 min in a water bath.
Add 10 mL of cR10.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in 10 mL of cR10.
Incubate at 37°C for 30 min in CO2 incubator.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant.
            Suspend the cells in 5 mL of cR10 (final cell concentration at
            2 × 105 cells/mL).
          
        Co-culture of CFSE-labeled YAC-1 and reMAIT cells.
        
Prepare 1.4 × 106 of reMAIT cells.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant.
            Resuspend the cells in 700 μL of cR10 (final concentration at
            2 × 106 cells/mL).
          
            Make the following dilution of reMAIT cells.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_17.csv
            Prepare 700 μL of 2 × 106 cells/mL NK cells in cR10 by
            using the NK cell suspension from step 34.
          
            Make the following dilution of NK cells.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_18.csv
            Plate CFSE-labeled YAC-1 (T:Target), reMAIT cells and NK cells
            (E:Effector) in triplicate in a 96-well V-bottom plate as shown in
            Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_19.csv
Incubate for 4 h at 37°C in a CO2 incubator.
        Live/dead staining using Zombie dye.
        
Dilute Zombie Violet in PBS at 1:500.
            After 4 h incubation, centrifuge the 96-well plate at 500 × g

for 5 min in a plate centrifuge.
          
            Dump the supernatant by quickly inverting and flicking the plate.
          
Add 100 μL of diluted Zombie Violet into each well.
Incubate at 20-25°C for 15 min, shielded from light.
            Add 100 μL of FACS buffer and centrifuge at 500 × g for
            5 min.
          
            Dump the supernatant by quickly inverting and flicking the plate.
            Scratch the bottom of the plate to loosen the cell pellets.
          
            Add 200 μL of FACS buffer and centrifuge at 500 × g for
            5 min.
          
            Dump the supernatant by quickly inverting and flicking the plate.
            Scratch the bottom of the plate to loosen the cell pellets.
          
Add 100 μL of FACS buffer.
Acquire the cells with a flow cytometer.
        Analyze the flow cytometric data (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3084-Fig3.jpg
              Figure 3. Gating strategy for measuring cytolytic activity of
              reMAIT cells (left panel) and reMAIT cells plus NK cells (right
              panel) against YAC-1(YAC)
            
              Most of the cells other than debris are gated in the scatter plots
              (leftmost columns). YAC-1 is detected as CFSE-positive (second
              columns from left); cells seen as CSFE-negative are the effector
              cells (reMAIT cells and/or NK cells). The percentage of Zombie
              positive cells (considered as dying or dead cells) among CFSE
              positive YAC-1 is shown as a histogram (second columns from
              right). Dead (or dying) YAC-1 (shown in red) are located in the
              diagonal on the scatter plots. Live YAC-1 is shown in blue. The
              cells indicated in light blue are CFSE-negative cells including
              the effector cells (reMAIT and NK) (rightmost columns).
            
        Calculate “percent lysis” using the following formula: {(% of Zombie+
        cells among target cells in the presence of effector cells) - (% of
        Zombie+ cells among target cells in the absence of effector
        cells)}/ {100 − (% of Zombie+ cells among target cells in the

absence of effector cells)}/100.
      
Note: Because YAC-1 culture contains many
      dead cells, a significant number of Zombie+ cells are detected
      even in the absence of effector cells (high background).
    
Critical: Be sure to use 1 μM CFSE.
      The use of more or less concentrated CFSE would make it difficult to
      identify the CSFE-positive cells within the FITC-channel in flow
      cytometry.
    
Cytolytic activity of reMAIT cells against LLC
Timing: 3 days
      LLC is adherent and is generally resistant to killing by cytolytic CD8+
      T cells and NK cells. We found that reMAIT cells can kill LLC by
      co-culturing for 16–20 h using the following strategies.
    
        Plating of LLC (Day 0).
        
            Trypsinize semi-confluent LLC and prepare 1 × 105
            cells/mL cell suspension in 8% FBS/DMEM.
          
            Spread 100 μL per well of the cell suspension into a 96-well
            flat-bottom culture plate (1 × 104 cells/well).
          
Incubate at 37°C for 16–20 h in CO2 incubator.
        Co-culture of LLC and reMAIT cells and/or NK cells (Day 1).
        
Prepare 3 × 106 of reMAIT cells.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant.
            Resuspend the cells in 1 mL of cR10 (final concentration at
            3 × 106 cells/mL).
          
            Make the following dilution for reMAIT cells.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_20.csv
            Prepare 1 mL of 3 × 106 cells/mL NK cells in cR10 by
            using the NK cell suspension from step 34.
          
            Make the following dilution of NK cells.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_21.csv
            Remove the medium from each well of 96-well plate of LLC culture
            (see step 47).
          
            Add appropriate amounts of reMAIT cells in a 96-well plate seeded
            with LLC in triplicate as shown in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
            table:files/protocols_protocol_3084_22.csv
Incubate for 16–20 h at 37°C in a CO2 incubator.
        Live/dead staining using Zombie dye (Day 2).
        
Dilute Zombie Violet in PBS at 1:1000.

Aspirate the medium from a 96-well plate.
Wash the wells with 200 μL of PBS.
            Add 30 μL of the diluted Zombie Violet solution into each well.
          
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 15 min, shielded from light.
Wash the wells with 200 μL of PBS twice.
Add 30 μL of 0.25% Trypsin-1 mM EDTA.
Incubate at 37°C for 5 min.
Add 70 μL of 10% FBS/DMEM.
Acquire the cells with a flow cytometer.
        Analyze the flow cytometric data (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).

              Figure 5. Anti-YAC-1 cytolytic activity of reMAIT cells and NK
              cells
            
              (A) Example data of % Zombie+ in YAC-1 according to the
              gating shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. The percentages of
              Zombie+ cells among YAC-1 in the presence of effector
              cells (experimental Zombie+ cells) are shown in blue,
              and the percentages of Zombie+ cells among YAC-1 in the
              absence of effector cells (spontaneous Zombie+ cells)
              are shown in red.
            
(B) The formula for calculating the percentage of lysis.
              (C) The percentages of lysis calculated by applying the values in
              (A) to the formula (B).
            
              (D) Cytolytic activity of reMAIT cells (reMAIT ●), NK cells (NK
              ◼), and NK cells plus reMAIT cells (NK + reMAIT ▲). Data (C) are
              plotted (% lysis vs. E/T ratio) as mean ± SD.
            
        Calculate “percent lysis” using the following formula: {(% of Zombie+
        cells among target cells in the presence of effector cells) - (% of
        Zombie+ cells among target cells in the absence of effector
        cells)}/ {100 − (% of Zombie+ cells among target cells in the
        absence of effector cells)}/100.
      
Note: NK cells alone would not lyse LLC.
    
Critical: Be sure to incubate LLC with
      reMAIT cells for 16–20 h. Less incubation time would compromise the lytic
      activity of reMAIT cells.
